Hien, said the mi$ (and I quote directly from the party statement)*
"the Italian divisions arrayed on the borders of the bloody Trieste Free
Territory should* without further ado, enter the martyred city to deliver
the Italian population from the persecutions and the carnage*"
It was not the only occasion on waieh the &SI had called for war,
if necessary, to settle the Trieste issue in Italy's favor* Sen* Frans
rurchi of the i-:3X declared that Italian divisions should Intervene •• as
he put it — to "defend from fruther massacre the Italian people of
Trieste*" Senator Turchi said that Premier Guiseppe Pella was "at the
crossroadsa" that Pella should "choose, and choose quickly" because
"Italian blood gushes with every instant lost#"
The MSI newspaper, Ji lecolp, said the hour had arrived when the
appeal should be "to courage, rather than to calm*" The time had arrived
for calling enemies enemies and for having a reckoning with what H leeolo
called, "those who have proclaimed themselves our saviors •• internally
and externally*" And jy> Geoolo added;
"Trieste has oelebratfd her vespers of rebellion and of revenge*
Trieste has given the initiative to the chasing out of the foreigner#
The foreigner must go; the eueajy {meaning, the British and oner leans, as
well as the Jugoslavs) must go!"
Hie newspaper ^prldlano a*Italia went further* It said: "We should
move the Bersagllerl toward San Giusto and free the Triestinea* Blood
calls for blood# Viva Trieste# Blood wants Justice* • •"
Hie newspaper ttoaa. the organ of the leader of the Italian
monarchist party, Achilla Lauro, had an interesting complaint to make*
Foma blasted the London correspondent of Kadlo Italians because he handled
the news of Foreign Secretary Eden's speech to the House of Commons in a
calm, objective manner#
